title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno of Google Cloud outlines how AI-aware networking (via GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing) targets the unique characteristics of AI inference to reduce latency, improve GPU utilization, and simplify governance. The approach uses inference-specific metrics, prefix caching, body-based routing, LoRA-awareness, and network-level service extensions to insert API management and guardrails into traffic flows.
bullets: Traditional networking and CPU-based metrics miss GPU/TPU saturation; inference-specific metrics (e.g., KV cache utilization, queue depth) are used to identify least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies of caches let the gateway reuse prefill computations to reduce GPU work and minimize cold starts.
Body-based routing and LoRA-awareness enable routing to the correct model/adapter instance and unify multi-model APIs.
Service Extensions let teams insert API management and AI guardrails at the network layer to sanitize prompts/responses before hitting models.
Products mentioned: GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing, and Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE).
takeaways: Expect better GPU saturation and fewer cold starts when networks use inference-aware metrics—this can lower per-inference compute costs and affect power/capacity planning.
Capacity and load-balancing decisions should be driven by inference metrics (KV cache utilization, queue depth) not just CPU, to avoid routing traffic to congested replicas.
Network-level guardrails that block invalid or disallowed prompts at the edge can prevent unnecessary GPU usage and reduce wasted compute spend.
Deploying these capabilities requires platform support (GKE Inference Gateway, Cloud Load Balancing) and may necessitate changes to network design and orchestration for AI workloads.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video focuses on anticipating an aging steam turbine rotor’s remaining life and outlining what steps to take next to preserve steam-plant reliability. It points viewers to a GE Vernova resource for more detail and references the company’s role in electrification and decarbonization efforts.
bullets: Emphasizes assessing remaining life of steam turbine rotors as central to plant reliability.
Frames rotor end-of-life (EOL) planning as a decision point — inspection, repair, or replacement.
Directs viewers to a GE Vernova resource for more information (rotor-EOL link).
Connects rotor lifecycle management to broader electrification and decarbonization context.
No transcript provided; summary based solely on the video description.
takeaways: Steam turbine rotor EOL assessment is critical to preventing unplanned outages that can impact grid stability and power for critical facilities (e.g., data centers).
Decision-makers should incorporate rotor life evaluations into maintenance and outage scheduling to manage risk and spare-parts logistics.
Include rotor lifecycle planning in long-term generation and decarbonization strategies to align reliability with transition goals.

items.title: How CNA accelerates risk assessment with Google Cloud Consulting

ai.summary: Based on the available description, CNA partnered with Google Cloud Consulting to modernize risk assessment and enable faster, data-driven decision-making. The team built a ground-up solution in six months that uses BigQuery and geospatial analytics to process terabytes of data for thousands of locations, helping underwriters save time and make more informed decisions.
bullets: CNA used BigQuery and geospatial analytics to process terabytes of location-based data.
Solution covered thousands of locations to support enterprise-wide risk assessment.
Google Cloud Consulting provided specialized technical expertise and accelerated delivery.
End result: faster, data-driven underwriting workflows and time savings for underwriters.
Project delivered from scratch in six months.
takeaways: Scalable cloud analytics (BigQuery) can handle terabyte-scale datasets needed for asset-risk analysis across large grids and distributed data center fleets.
Geospatial analytics are directly applicable for assessing site-specific risks (substations, transmission corridors, data centers, renewables sites).
Partnering with specialized cloud consultants can compress delivery timelines for critical analytics platforms—useful when rapid risk insights are required.
Faster, data-driven risk assessment can reduce decision latency for operations, maintenance planning, and site hardening investments.

items.title: Power Up Your Skills with SCADA Ultimate: Solutions & Training

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova’s SCADA Ultimate bundles SCADA, Historian, and Analytics into a single offering intended to support customers’ digital and analytics journeys. The release also highlights new training opportunities and guidance on maximizing benefits across GE Vernova’s Proficy product portfolio.
bullets: SCADA Ultimate integrates SCADA, Historian, and Analytics capabilities.
Designed to help advance customers’ digital and analytics initiatives.
New training opportunities announced to support users and clients.
Guidance provided on maximizing value across the Proficy software portfolio.
Supporting links direct viewers to GE Vernova and Proficy product pages.
takeaways: Assess SCADA Ultimate as a combined SCADA/Hist./Analytics option when planning digital upgrades for substations, transmission operations, or data center power management.
Consider enrolling operators and engineers in the announced training to increase adoption and operational competency.
Review the Proficy product portfolio (linked in the description) to determine how the integrated offering fits existing systems and digital strategies.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection has made reliability its primary focus since 1927. The video is presented as an overview of how PJM works to make sure electricity is there when you need it.
bullets: PJM Interconnection has prioritized electricity reliability since 1927.
The video intends to explain how PJM ensures power is available when needed.
No transcript is provided, so specific operational details are not available in the description.
Content is relevant to anyone concerned with regional electricity reliability, including transmission, substations, and critical loads like data centers and AI infrastructure.
takeaways: Treat PJM as a primary regional source for electricity reliability guidance given its long-established role.
Data center and AI infrastructure teams should consult PJM materials to understand regional expectations for power availability.
Transmission and substation planners should reference PJM guidance to align local reliability practices with the regional operator.
Because the transcript is unavailable, view the video or visit PJM’s official resources for actionable, operational details.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the video frames grid modernization as a need to balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. It states that Hitachi Energy presents digital-first power grid technologies aimed at improving stability, reducing downtime, and optimizing performance across system levels.
bullets: Grid modernization must balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency as capacity expands for the energy transition.
Digital technologies are presented as core to improving grid stability.
Emphasis on reducing downtime and optimizing performance across transmission and distribution systems.
Solution framing applies across system levels rather than a single asset class.
Target outcomes align with supporting greater renewable integration and load growth.
takeaways: Prioritize digital capabilities when selecting upgrades to improve stability and reduce outage risk.
Consider technologies that optimize performance system-wide, not just at individual substations.
Reducing downtime is critical for infrastructure supporting data centers and other critical loads.
Flexibility and efficiency improvements will ease integration of renewables and growing capacity needs.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, resilient industries rely on energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration. Hitachi Energy says it works with customers and partners to build smarter systems that improve productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Focus areas: energy efficiency, process optimization, digital integration.
Collaboration model: working with customers and partners to implement solutions.
Objectives: improve productivity, reliability, and sustainability of operations.
Target audience: industrial operators and infrastructure owners seeking smarter systems.
More information available via the provided link.
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency and process-optimization projects to strengthen operational resilience.
Evaluate digital-integration platforms that can tie together operations for improved reliability and productivity.
Engage technology partners to co-develop tailored systems rather than adopting one-size-fits-all solutions.
Assess sustainability outcomes of new systems alongside reliability and productivity when making procurement decisions.

items.title: Air Taxis Are Coming to Dubai

ai.summary: Based on the available description (no transcript provided), Joby Aviation is likely to begin an air-taxi service in Dubai in 2026 that would shuttle passengers across the city to help them avoid road traffic. The announcement frames this as an urban air-mobility rollout of air taxis in Dubai next year.
bullets: No transcript available; summary relies on the video description only.
Joby Aviation is likely to start air-taxi operations in Dubai in 2026.
Service is pitched as fast city shuttles to beat surface traffic.
Framing and tags identify this as eVTOL / urban air mobility rather than conventional aviation.
takeaways: If Joby’s eVTOL service launches, concentrated vertiports/landing sites could create localized new electrical loads — utilities and planners should assess distribution and substation capacity near likely hubs.
Allow for lead times on permitting and physical upgrades around busy urban landing locations; early coordination with city power planners can reduce deployment bottlenecks.
Data-center and comms operators supporting air-taxi operations should consider resilience and backup power needs for critical communications and control systems at vertiports and command centers.

Electrification of urban air mobility implies attention to charging infrastructure and associated supply chains (battery hardware/critical materials) when evaluating long‑term capacity and procurement planning.
